column1: Task1: Provide five reasons for creating a conceptual data model.
1.Conceptual Model can captures the functional and infornational needs for a business
2.Reflect future needs based on current needs, address the needs of a business
3.conceptual model simplifies the overall design process. This helps in managing the complexity of large systems.
4.The conceptual model serves as a blueprint that guides the creation of logical and physical data models
5.Conceptual data models help ensure that data is consistently represented across the organization.

2. Read each relationship in the model below. For each relationship, write the ERD statement and your comments. Use your knowledge of normal people and towns in your comments.
Person born in Town: Each PERSON can be born in only one TOWN, but a TOWN can be the birthplace of many PERSONS.
Person living in Town: A PERSON can live in one or more TOWNS, and a TOWN can have many PERSONS living in it.
Person hometown of Town: Each PERSON has one hometown (TOWN), but a TOWN can be the hometown of many PERSONS.
Person visitor of Town: A PERSON can visit multiple TOWNS, and a TOWN can have many visitors (PERSONS).
Person mayor of Town: Each TOWN can have only one PERSON as a mayor, but a PERSON can only be the mayor of one TOWN.
Person governed by Town: This might indicate governance relationships, typically implying many-to-one or many-to-many associations depending on context.
1.ERDish Descriptions for Relationships in the Academic Database:
ERDish: Each DEPARTMENT offers one or more COURSES. Each COURSE is offered by exactly one DEPARTMENT.
Optionality: Mandatory for both COURSE and DEPARTMENT
ERDish: Each STUDENT enrolls in one or more COURSES. Each COURSE can have many STUDENTS enrolled.
Optionality: Mandatory for both STUDENT and COURSE.
ERDish: Each FACULTY teaches one or more COURSES. Each COURSE is taught by exactly one FACULTY.
Optionality: Mandatory for both COURSE and FACULTY.
ERDish: Each STUDENT takes one or more EXAMS. Each EXAM is taken by one or more STUDENTS.
Optionality: Mandatory for both STUDENT and EXAM.
ERDish: Each STUDENT can have one or more PARENTS. Each PARENT is associated with exactly one STUDENT.
Optionality: Mandatory for PARENT, optional for STUDENT.
ERDish: Each ACADEMIC SESSION includes one or more COURSES. Each COURSE is offered in one or more ACADEMIC SESSIONS.
Optionality: Mandatory for both COURSE and SESSION.
ERDish: Each FACULTY has one or more LOGIN LOG entries. Each LOGIN LOG entry is for exactly one FACULTY.
Optionality: Mandatory for LOGIN LOG, optional for FACULTY.
Draw the ERD including the relationships.
1.Identify the possible Entities and Attributes from the given scenario.
Department-Supervisor: A Department has one Supervisor, and each Supervisor is assigned to one Department. (One-to-One relationship)
Department-Employee: A Department has many Employees, and each Employee must be assigned to at least one Department. (One-to-Many relationship)
Employee-Project: An Employee can be assigned to many Projects, and a Project can have many Employees. (Many-to-Many relationship)

StylistID (Primary Key, mandatory) - Unique identifier for each hairstylist.
column2: FirstName (mandatory) - First name of the hairstylist.
column3: LastName (mandatory) - Last name of the hairstylist.
column5: PhoneNumber (mandatory) - Phone number of the hairstylist.

column1: ClientID (Primary Key, mandatory) - Unique identifier for each client.
column2: FirstName (mandatory) - First name of the client.
column3: LastName (optional) - Last name of the client (only for those who make an appointment).
column4: PhoneNumber (optional) - Phone number of the client (only for those who make an appointment).

column1: ERDish: A HAIRSTYLIST can serve zero or more CLIENTS in a day, and a CLIENT can be assigned to only one HAIRSTYLIST per visit.
Cardinality: One-to-Many (1) from HAIRSTYLIST to CLIENT.
HAIRSTYLIST: A HAIRSTYLIST may not have any clients on a slow day (optional relationship on the CLIENT side).
CLIENT: Every CLIENT is assigned to one HAIRSTYLIST (mandatory relationship on the CLIENT side).

3.Read the given business scenario. Draw the entities TEACHER and COURSE and CLASS. List the attributes underneath each entity. Specify whether they are mandatory or optional. Identify the UIDs. . State the ERDish for the relationships.
TeacherID (Primary Key, mandatory) - Unique identifier for each teacher.
column2: FirstName (mandatory) - First name of the teacher.
column3: LastName (mandatory) - Last name of the teacher.
column5: PhoneNumber (mandatory) - Phone number of the teacher.
column6: EmailAddress (mandatory) - Email address of the teacher.

column1: CourseCode (Primary Key, mandatory) - Unique code for each course.
column2: CourseName (mandatory) - Name of the course (e.g., Data Modeling, Trigonometry

column1: ClassID (Primary Key, mandatory) - Unique identifier for each class.
column2: Day (mandatory) - The day of the week the class is taught.
column3: Time (mandatory) - The time of day the class is taught.
column4: Classroom (mandatory) - The classroom where the class is taught.
column5: TeacherID (Foreign Key, optional) - References the teacher assigned to the class.
column6: CourseCode (Foreign Key, mandatory) - References the course that the class covers.

column1: ERDish: A TEACHER can teach zero, one, or more CLASSES in a semester, and each CLASS is taught by exactly one TEACHER.
Cardinality: One-to-Many (1) from TEACHER to CLASS.
TEACHER: A TEACHER may not teach any classes if on sabbatical (optional relationship on the CLASS side).
CLASS: Every CLASS must be assigned a TEACHER (mandatory relationship on the CLASS side).
ERDish: A COURSE can be taught in one or more CLASSES in a semester, and each CLASS is associated with exactly one COURSE.
Cardinality: One-to-Many (1) from COURSE to CLASS.
COURSE: A COURSE must have at least one CLASS (mandatory relationship on the CLASS side).
CLASS: Each CLASS must belong to exactly one COURSE (mandatory relationship on the COURSE side).

a. Why is the start time part of the UID of ASSIGNMENT?
The start time is part of the unique identifier (UID) of the ASSIGNMENT entity because the combination of Date of Exam and Start Time uniquely identifies a specific instance of an assignment.
b. Name at least three time-related constraints.
1.End Time must be later than Start Time:
Constraint: The End Time of an exam must always be later than the Start Time.
Conditional Non-Transferability: This constraint is not about transferability but is a logical constraint to ensure that the duration of an exam is valid.
2.Exams on the Same Date in the Same Classroom Should Not Overlap:
Constraint: If two exams are scheduled in the same Class Room on the same Date of Exam, their times must not overlap. This means that one exam must end before the next one begins.
Conditional Non-Transferability: This constraint implies that time slots for classroom assignments cannot be reused or transferred if they overlap with another assignment.
3.Minimum Duration Between Exams in the Same Classroom:
Constraint: There should be a minimum gap (e.g., 15 minutes) between the end of one exam and the start of another in the same classroom. This allows for setup or transition time.
Conditional Non-Transferability: This constraint ensures that there is adequate time between assignments, preventing the direct transfer of time slots without considering this gap.
The Color column contains multiple values in some rows, which violates the 1NF requirement of atomicity.
Split the Rows with Multiple Colors:
Each combination of Item ID and Color should have its own row.

The Location attribute is dependent only on Store ID and not on the full composite key (Supplier ID and Store ID). This violates the rule of 2NF, which states that all non-key attributes must be fully functionally dependent on the entire primary key.
Location is partially dependent on Store ID alone, not on the entire composite key.
To remove the partial dependency, we need to split the table into two separate tables.
This table will store the relationship between Store ID and Location.
This table will maintain the relationship between Supplier ID and Store ID.

The table violates the Third Normal Form (3NF) because of the transitive dependency. Specifically, Category Desc depends on Category ID, and Category ID is not the primary key but a non-key attribute. This means Category Desc is indirectly dependent on the primary key Book ID through Category ID.
Category Desc is transitively dependent on Book ID through Category ID.

To remove the transitive dependency, separate the table into two tables: one for the relationship between Category ID and Category Desc, and another for the relationship between Book ID, Category ID, and Price.
Book Table:This table will store the relationship between Book ID, Category ID, and Price.
Category Table:will store the relationship between Category ID and Category Desc.
1. Evaluate the Entities Against the Rules of Normalization:
1NF: The entity is in 1NF as all the attributes contain atomic values.
2NF: The entity is in 2NF because the primary key is not composite, so all non-key attributes are fully dependent on the primary key.
3NF: There are no transitive dependencies, so it complies with 3NF.
1NF: The entity is in 1NF as all attributes are atomic.
2NF: The entity is in 2NF because the primary key is not composite.
3NF: The entity complies with 3NF, as there are no transitive dependencies.
1NF: This entity lacks a clear primary key, which is required for 1NF. We need a composite key of StudentID and CourseID to properly normalize it.
2NF: Assuming a composite key of StudentID and CourseID, Grade would be fully dependent on the composite key.
3NF: The entity would be in 3NF with the composite key since there would be no transitive dependencies.
1NF, 2NF, 3NF: The entity complies with all forms of normalization.
1NF, 2NF, 3NF: The entity complies with all forms of normalization.
1NF, 2NF, 3NF: The entity complies with all forms of normalization.
1NF, 2NF, 3NF: The subtypes comply with all forms of normalization.
1NF, 2NF, 3NF: The entity complies with all forms of normalization.
1NF: This entity lacks a clear primary key, which is required for 1NF. We need a composite key of StudentID and ExamID to properly normalize it.
2NF: Assuming a composite key of StudentID and ExamID, Grade would be fully dependent on the composite key.
3NF: The entity would be in 3NF with the composite key since there would be no transitive dependencies.
1NF Violations: Occur when there are missing or unclear primary keys that prevent proper identification of rows.
2NF Violations: Occur when non-key attributes depend on only part of a composite primary key, which wasn’t seen here.

3NF Violations: Occur when non-key attributes depend on other non-key attributes (transitive dependency), which wasn't observed in the primary entities but might occur in subtypes if not handled properly.
Book and Author: One-to-Many (One author can write many books).
Book and Publisher: One-to-Many (One publisher can publish many books).
Warehouse and Book (Stock): Many-to-Many (A book can be stocked in multiple warehouses, and a warehouse can stock multiple books). This relationship is managed by the Stock entity.
Customer and ShoppingCart: One-to-Many (One customer can own multiple shopping carts).
ShoppingCart and Book: Many-to-Many (A shopping cart can contain multiple books, and a book can be in multiple shopping carts). This is managed by the ShoppingCart entity.
ShoppingCart and Order: One-to-One (Each shopping cart leads to one order).
Books: Each book must have a unique ISBN. Books can have one or more authors but must have a single publisher.
Authors: Each author can write multiple books. The author’s information must include a homepage URL.
Publishers: Each publisher can publish multiple books. The publisher’s information must include a phone number and website URL.
Warehouses: Warehouses can stock multiple books. The quantity of each book in a warehouse must be tracked.
Customers: Customers can have multiple shopping carts. Customer information must include a valid email address.
Shopping Carts: Each shopping cart can contain multiple books, with the possibility of multiple copies of the same book. The total number of copies per book in a shopping cart must be recorded.

Orders: Each shopping cart results in one order. The order must capture billing and shipping details, payment information, and the date the order was placed. A notification must be sent to the customer once the order is placed.
Each book must have a unique ISBN
A customer must provide billing and shipping information before placing an order.
If a customer’s order total exceeds $100, apply a 10% discount.
A book can be stocked at multiple warehouses
A book can be stocked at multiple warehouses
A customer can have multiple shopping carts
